standard_metadata.standard_description: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction or whole number by a fraction.

question.content: Use the number line below to help solve the multiplication problem.        **What is $\dfrac{6}{7}$ of $\dfrac{2}{3}$?**

images.alt: A number line starting at 0 has minor tick marks every one twenty-first unit and major tick marks every one-third unit. The major tick marks are labeled from left to right: zero, one-third, and two-thirds, one. The number line is shaded from the 0 tick mark to the sixth tick mark after 0 and from the one-third tick mark to the sixth tick mark after one-third.  Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 3 equal parts. Each part is further divided into 7 smaller parts for a total of 21 smaller parts. The first 6 parts and parts 8 through 13 are shaded in dark green. The dark green parts are between 0 and the sixth tick mark after 0 and between one-third and the sixth tick mark after one-third on the number line. Seventh and fourteenth parts are shaded in light green. The light green parts are between the sixth tick mark after 0 and one-third tick mark and between the sixth tick mark after one-third and two-thirds tick mark on the number line.

hints.content: First we find $2$ thirds on the number line.  [[☃ image 1]]  We can't split $2$ pieces into a whole number of sevenths, so we'll split every piece into $7$ equal parts instead.  [[☃ image 2]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-third unit. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 3 equal parts. The first two parts are shaded. The shaded parts are between 0 and two-thirds tick marks on the number line.

A number line starting at 0 has minor tick marks every one twenty-first unit and major tick marks every one-third unit. The major tick marks are labeled from left to right: zero, one-third, and  two-thirds, one. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 3 equal parts. Each part is further divided into 7 smaller parts for a total of 21 smaller parts. The first 14 parts are shaded. The shaded parts are between 0 and two-thirds tick marks on the number line.  A curved bracket above the shaded parts of the fraction bar is labeled two-thirds.

hints.content: Then we shade $\dfrac{6}{7}$ of every third on the number line.  [[☃ image 1]]  There are $2\times 6 = 12$ parts shaded on the number line.

images.alt: A number line starting at 0 has minor tick marks every one twenty-first unit and major tick marks every one-third unit. The major tick marks are labeled from left to right: zero, one-third, and  two-thirds, one. The number line is shaded from the 0 tick mark to the sixth tick mark after 0 and from the one-third tick mark to the sixth tick mark after one-third. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 3 equal parts. Each part is further divided into 7 smaller parts for a total of 21 smaller parts. The first 6 parts and parts 8 through 13 are shaded in dark green. The dark green parts are between 0 and the sixth tick mark after 0 and between one-third and the sixth tick mark after one-third on the number line. Seventh and fourteenth parts are shaded in light green. The light green parts are between the sixth tick mark after 0 and one third tick mark and between the sixth tick mark after one-third and two-thirds tick mark on the number line. A curved bracket above the first seven shaded parts of the fraction bar is labeled one-third. A curved bracket above the eighth through fourteenth shaded parts of the fraction bar is labeled one-third.

hints.content: There are $7 \times 3 = 21$ parts per whole, so each part is $\dfrac{1}{21}$.   [[☃ image 1]]  We shaded $12$ of the $21$ equal parts on the number line, so $\dfrac{6}{7}$ of $\dfrac{2}{3}=\dfrac{12}{21}$.

images.alt: A number line starting at 0 has minor tick marks every one twenty-first unit and major tick marks every one third unit. The major tick marks are labeled from left to right: zero, one-third, and two-thirds, one. The number line is shaded from the 0 tick mark to the sixth tick mark after 0 and from the one-third  tick mark to the sixth tick mark after one-third. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 3 equal parts. Each part is further divided into 7 smaller parts for a total of 21 smaller parts. Each part is labeled one twenty-first. A curved bracket above the entire fraction bar is labeled 1.

hints.content: We can also solve using multiplication.    $\dfrac{6}{7}$ of $\dfrac23$ is another way of saying $\dfrac67 \times \dfrac23$.
$\begin{align} \dfrac67\text{ of }\dfrac23& = \dfrac67 \times \dfrac23\\\\ &=\dfrac{6 \times 2}{7 \times 3}\\\\ &= \dfrac{12}{21} \end{align}$

We can rewrite $\dfrac{12}{21}$ as an equivalent fraction.  $\begin{align} \dfrac{12}{21}&=\dfrac{4 \times 3}{7 \times 3}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4}{7}\times\dfrac{3}{3}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4}{7}\times1\\\\ &=\dfrac{4}{7} \end{align}$
$\dfrac67$ of $\dfrac23$ is $\dfrac47$ .

question.content: Use the number line below to help solve the multiplication problem.      **What is $\dfrac{3}{4}$ of $\dfrac{2}{5}$?**

images.alt: A fraction bar divided into 20 equal parts. The left 8 parts are shaded in a pattern: 3 dark parts, 1 light part, 3 dark parts, 1 light part. The right 12 sections of the fraction bar are not shaded. Below the fraction bar, there is a number line the same length as the fraction bar. A number line below the fraction bar is labeled 0 to 1 with minor tick marks every one-twentieth unit and major tick marks every one-fifth unit. Two lines move right across the number line. The first line moves right three tick marks from 0 to the tick mark before one-fifth. The second line moves right three tick marks from one-fifth to the tick mark before two-fifths.

hints.content: First we find $2$ fifths on the number line.  [[☃ image 1]]  Let's split every piece into $4$ equal parts.  [[☃ image 2]]

images.alt: A fraction bar divided into five equal parts. Two of the parts are shaded. Below the fraction bar, there is a number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-fifth unit. The shaded area of the fraction bar runs between tick mark 0 and tick mark two-fifths on the number line.

A fraction bar divided into 20 equal parts. The left 8 parts are shaded. The right 12 sections of the fraction bar are not shaded. Across the shaded parts is a curved bracket labeled two-fifths. Below the fraction bar, there is a number line the same length as the fraction bar. The number line is labeled 0 to 1 with minor tick marks every one-twentieth unit and major tick marks every one-fifth unit.

hints.content: Then we shade $\dfrac{3}{4}$ of every fifth on the number line.   [[☃ image 1]]  There are $3\times 2 = 6$ parts shaded on the number line.

images.alt: A fraction bar divided into 20 equal parts. The left 8 parts are shaded in a pattern: 3 dark parts, 1 light part, 3 dark parts, 1 light part. The right 12 sections of the fraction bar are not shaded. Across the first three shaded parts is a curved bracket labeled three-fourths times one-fifth. Below the fraction bar, there is a number line the same length as the fraction bar. The number line is labeled 0 to 1 with minor tick marks every one-twentieth unit and major tick marks every one-fifth unit. Two lines move right across the number line. The first line moves right three tick marks from 0 to the tick mark before one-fifth. The second line moves right three tick marks from one-fifth to the tick mark before two-fifths.

hints.content: There are $4 \times 5 = 20$ parts per whole, so each part is $\dfrac{1}{20}$.    [[☃ image 1]]  We shaded $6$ of the $20$ equal parts on the number line, so $\dfrac{3}{4}$ of $\dfrac{2}{5}=\dfrac{6}{20}$.

images.alt: A fraction bar divided into 20 equal parts, each labeled one-twentieth. Across the fraction bar is a curved bracket labeled 1. Below the fraction bar, there is a number line the same length as the fraction bar. The number line is labeled 0 to 1 with minor tick marks every one-twentieth unit and major tick marks every one-fifth unit.

hints.content: We can also solve using multiplication.    $\dfrac{3}{4}$ of $\dfrac{2}{5}$is another way of saying $\dfrac{3}{4} \times \dfrac{2}{5}$.
$\begin{align} \dfrac34\text{ of }\dfrac25& = \dfrac34 \times \dfrac25\\\\ &=\dfrac{3 \times 2}{4 \times 5}\\\\ &= \dfrac{6}{20} \end{align}$

We can rewrite $\dfrac{6}{20}$ as an equivalent fraction.  $\begin{align} \dfrac{6}{20}&=\dfrac{3 \times 2}{10 \times 2}\\\\ &=\dfrac{3}{10}\times\dfrac{2}{2}\\\\ &=\dfrac{3}{10}\times1\\\\ &=\dfrac{3}{10} \end{align}$
$\dfrac34$ of $\dfrac25$ is $\dfrac3{10}$ .

question.content: Use the number line below to help solve the multiplication problem.      **What is $\dfrac{3}{8}$ of $\dfrac{1}{4}$?**

images.alt: A number line starting at 0 to 1 with minor tick marks every one thirty-second unit and major tick marks every one-fourth unit. The major tick marks are labeled from left to right: zero, one-fourth, one-half, three-fourths, and 1. The number line is shaded from the 0 tick mark to the third tick mark after 0. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 4 equal parts. Each part is further divided into 8 smaller parts for a total of 32 smaller parts. The first 3 parts are shaded in dark purple. The dark purple parts are between 0 and the third tick mark after 0 on the number line. The next 5 parts are shaded in light purple. The light purple parts are between the third tick mark after 0 and one-fourth tick mark on the number line.

hints.content: First we find $1$ fourth on the number line.  [[☃ image 1]]  We can't split $1$ piece into a whole number of eighths, so we'll split every piece into $8$ equal parts instead.  [[☃ image 2]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-fourth unit. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 4 equal parts. The first part is shaded. The shaded part is between 0 and one-fourth on the number line.

A number line starting at 0 to 1 with minor tick marks every one thirty-second unit and major tick marks every one-fourth unit. The major tick marks are labeled from left to right: zero, one-fourth, one-half, three-fourths, and 1. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 4 equal parts. Each part is 
further divided into 8 smaller parts for a total of 32 smaller parts. The first 8 parts are shaded in light purple. The light purple parts are between the 0 tick mark and one-fourth tick mark on the number line. A curved bracket above the 8 light purple parts is labeled one-fourth.

hints.content: Then we shade $\dfrac{3}{8}$ of every fourth on the number line.   [[☃ image 1]]  There are $3\times 1 = 3$ parts shaded on the number line.

images.alt: A number line starting at 0 to 1 with minor tick marks every one thirty-second unit and major tick marks every one-fourth unit. The major tick marks are labeled from left to right: zero, one-fourth, one-half, three-fourths, and 1. The number line is shaded from the 0 tick mark to the third tick mark after 0. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 4 equal parts. Each part is further divided into 8 smaller parts for a total of 32 smaller parts. The first 3 parts are shaded in dark purple. The dark purple parts are between 0 and the third tick mark after 0 on the number line. The next 5 parts are shaded in light purple. The light purple parts are between the third tick mark after 0 and one-fourth tick mark on the number line. A curved bracket above the 3 dark purple parts is labeled three-eighths times one-fourth.

hints.content: There are $8 \times 4 = 32$ parts per whole, so each part is $\dfrac{1}{32}$.  We shaded $3$ of the $32$ equal parts on the number line, so $\dfrac{3}{8}$ of $\dfrac{1}{4}=\dfrac{3}{32}$.
We can also solve using multiplication.    $\dfrac{3}{8}$ of $\dfrac14$is another way of saying $\dfrac{3}{8} \times \dfrac14$.
$\begin{align} \dfrac38\text{ of }\dfrac14& = \dfrac38 \times \dfrac14\\\\ &=\dfrac{3 \times 1}{8 \times 4}\\\\ &= \dfrac{3}{32} \end{align}$
$\dfrac38$ of $\dfrac14$ is $\dfrac3{32}$ .

question.content: Use the number line below to help solve the multiplication problem.      **What is $\dfrac56$ of $\dfrac12$?**

images.alt: A number line starting at 0 to 1 with minor tick marks every one twelfth unit and major tick marks every one-half unit. The major tick marks are labeled from left to right: zero, one-half, and 1. The number line is shaded from the 0 tick mark to the fifth tick mark after 0.  Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 2 equal parts. Each part is further divided into 6 smaller parts for a total of 12 smaller parts. The first 5 parts are shaded in dark blue. The dark blue parts are between 0 and the fifth tick mark after 0 on the number line. The sixth part is shaded in light blue. The light blue part is between the fifth tick mark after 0 and one-half tick mark on the number line.

hints.content: First we find $1$ half on the number line.  [[☃ image 1]]  We can't split $1$ piece into a whole number of sixths, so we'll split every piece into $6$ equal parts instead.   [[☃ image 2]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-half unit. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 2 equal parts. The first part is shaded. The shaded part is between 0 and one-half tick marks on the number line.

A number line starting at 0 to 1 with minor tick marks every one twelfth unit and major tick marks every one-half unit. The major tick marks are labeled from left to right: zero, one-half, and 1.  Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 2 equal parts. Each part is further divided into 6 smaller parts for a total of 12 smaller parts. The first 6 parts are shaded. The shaded parts are between 0 and one-half tick marks on the number line. A curved bracket above the 6 shaded parts is labeled one-half.

hints.content: Then we shade $\dfrac{5}{6}$ of every half on the number line.   [[☃ image 1]]  There are $1\times 5 = 5$ parts shaded on the number line.

images.alt: A number line starting at 0 to 1 with minor tick marks every one twelfth unit and major tick marks every one-half unit. The major tick marks are labeled from left to right: zero, one-half, and 1. The number line is shaded from the 0 tick mark to the fifth tick mark after 0.  Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 2 equal parts. Each part is further divided into 6 smaller parts for a total of 12 smaller parts. The first 5 parts are shaded in dark blue. The dark blue parts are between 0 and the fifth tick mark after 0 on the number line. The sixth part is shaded in light blue. The light blue part is between the fifth tick mark after 0 and one-half tick mark on the number line. A curved bracket above the 6 shaded parts is labeled one-half.

hints.content: There are $6 \times 2 = 12$ parts per whole, so each part is $\dfrac{1}{12}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  We shaded $5$ of the $12$ equal parts on the number line, so $\dfrac{5}{6}$ of $\dfrac{1}{2}=\dfrac{5}{12}$.

images.alt: A number line starting at 0 to 1 with minor tick marks every one twelfth unit and major tick marks every one-half unit. The major tick marks are labeled from left to right: zero, one-half, and 1. The number line is shaded from the 0 tick mark to the fifth tick mark after 0. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 2 equal parts. Each part is further divided into 6 smaller parts for a total of 12 smaller parts. Each part is labeled one-twelfth. A curved bracket above the entire fraction bar is labeled 1.

hints.content: We can also solve using multiplication.    $\dfrac56$ of $\dfrac12$is another way of saying $\dfrac56 \times \dfrac12$.
$\begin{align} \dfrac56\text{ of }\dfrac12& = \dfrac56 \times \dfrac12\\\\ &=\dfrac{5 \times 1}{6 \times 2}\\\\ &= \dfrac{5}{12} \end{align}$
$\dfrac56$ of $\dfrac12$ is $\dfrac5{12}$ .

question.content: Use the number line below to help solve the multiplication problem.      **What is $\dfrac23$ of $\dfrac9{10}$?**

images.alt: A number line starting at 0 to 1 with ick marks every one-tenth unit. The tick marks are labeled from left to right: one-tenth, two-tenths, three-tenths, four-tenths, five-tenths, six-tenths, seven-tenths, eight-tenths, nine-tenths, and 1. The number line is shaded from the 0 tick mark to the six-tenths tick mark. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 10 equal parts. The first 6 parts are shaded in dark purple. The dark blue parts are between 0 and six-tenths tick marks on the number line. The next 3 parts are shaded in light purple. The light purple parts are between the sixth-tenths and nine-tenths tick marks on the number line.

hints.content: First we find $9$ tenths on the number line.  [[☃ image 1]]  We can split $9$ pieces into a whole number of thirds  [[☃ image 2]]  Every $\dfrac{3}{10}$ equals $\dfrac{1}{3}$ of $\dfrac{9}{10}$.  Then we shade $2$ of the thirds.

images.alt: A number line starting at 0 to 1 with ick marks every one-tenth unit. The tick marks are labeled from left to right: one-tenth, two-tenths, three-tenths, four-tenths, five-tenths, six-tenths, seven-tenths, eight-tenths, nine-tenths, and 1. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 10 equal parts. The first 9 parts are shaded in light purple. The light purple parts are between 0 and nine-tenths tick marks on the number line.

A number line starting at 0 to 1 with ick marks every one-tenth unit. The tick marks are labeled from left to right: one-tenth, two-tenths, three-tenths, four-tenths, five-tenths, six-tenths, seven-tenths, eight-tenths, nine-tenths, and 1. The number line is shaded from the 0 tick mark to the six-tenths tick mark. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 10 equal parts. The first 6 parts are shaded in dark purple. The dark blue parts are between 0 and six-tenths tick marks on the number line. The next 3 parts are shaded in light purple. The light purple parts are between the sixth-tenths and nine-tenths tick marks on the number line. An orange line between the third and fourth parts of the fraction bar  extends to the three-tenths tick mark on the number line. Another orange line between the sixth and seventh parts of the fraction bar extends to the six-tenths tick mark on the number line.

hints.content: We shaded $6$ of the $10$ equal parts on the number line, so $\dfrac{2}{3}$ of $\dfrac{9}{10}$ is $\dfrac{6}{10}$.
We can also solve using multiplication.    $\dfrac23$ of $\dfrac9{10}$is another way of saying $\dfrac23 \times \dfrac9{10}$.
$\begin{align} \dfrac23\text{ of }\dfrac9{10} & = \dfrac23 \times \dfrac9{10}\\\\ &=\dfrac{2 \times 9}{3 \times 10}\\\\ &= \dfrac{18}{30} \end{align}$

We can rewrite $\dfrac{18}{30}$ as an equivalent fraction.  $\begin{align} \dfrac{18}{30}&=\dfrac{3 \times 6}{5 \times 6}\\\\ &=\dfrac{3}{5}\times\dfrac{6}{6}\\\\ &=\dfrac{3}{5}\times1\\\\ &=\dfrac{3}{5} \end{align}$
$\dfrac23$ of $\dfrac9{10}$ is $\dfrac3{5}$ .

question.content: The area of the entire figure below is $1$ square unit.      Use the striped area to help solve the multiplication problem.      **What is $\dfrac{1}{3}$ of $\dfrac{1}{6}$?**     of a square unit

images.alt: A square that has been split into 18 parts set in 6 rows of 3 parts each. The parts in the topmost row have been shaded blue. The parts in the leftmost column have been shaded purple. The first part in the topmost row is striped to show it is shaded both blue and purple. Along the top of the square, the columns are labeled one-third. Along the left side of the square, the rows are labeled one-sixth.

hints.content: The area of the entire figure is $1$ square unit.  [[☃ image 1]]  The striped rectangle is $\purpleE{\dfrac13}$ of a unit wide.  Only $\blueE{\dfrac16}$ of the $\purpleE{\dfrac13}$ of the unit is striped.

images.alt: A square that has been split into 18 parts set in 6 rows of 3 parts each. The parts in the topmost row have been shaded blue. The parts in the leftmost column have been shaded purple. The first part in the topmost row is striped to show it is shaded both blue and purple. Along the top of the square, the columns are labeled one-third. Across the first column a bracket is labeled one-third. Along the left side of the square, the rows are labeled one-sixth. Across the first row a bracket is labeled one-sixth.

hints.content: What is $\blueE{\dfrac16}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac13}$?   We can see that $1$ of the $18$ equal parts from the whole unit has stripes.    $\blueE{\dfrac16}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac13}=\dfrac1{18}$

We can also solve with multiplication.  $\blueE{\dfrac16}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac13}$ is another way of saying $\blueE{\dfrac16} \times \purpleE{\dfrac13}$.  So we can calculate the area of the striped rectangle by multiplying its $\blueE{\text{height}} \times \purpleE{\text{width}}$.

$\begin{align} \text{Area of striped rectangle} &= \blueE{\text{height}} \times \purpleE{\text{width}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac16} \times \purpleE{\dfrac13}\\\\ & = \dfrac{\blueE{1} \times \purpleE{1}}{\blueE{6} \times \purpleE{3}}\\\\ & = \dfrac{1}{18} \end{align}$
The area of the striped rectangle is $\dfrac{1}{18}$ of a square unit.

question.content: The area of the entire figure below is $1$ square unit.      Use the striped area to help solve the multiplication problem.      **What is $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of $\dfrac{1}{5}$?**     of a square unit

images.alt: A square that has been split into 20 parts, set in 5 rows of 4 parts each. The parts in the topmost row have been shaded blue. The parts in the leftmost  column have been shaded purple. The first part in the topmost row is striped to show it is shaded both blue and purple. Along the top of the square, the columns are labeled one-fourth. Along the left side of the square, the rows are labeled one-fifth.

hints.content: The area of the entire figure is $1$ square unit.  [[☃ image 1]]  The striped rectangle is $\purpleE{\dfrac14}$ of a unit wide.  Only $\blueE{\dfrac15}$ of the $\purpleE{\dfrac14}$ of the unit is striped.

images.alt: A square that has been split into 20 parts set in 5 rows of 4 parts each. The parts in the topmost row have been shaded blue. The parts in the leftmost column have been shaded purple. The first part in the topmost row is striped to show it is shaded both blue and purple. Along the top of the square, the columns are labeled one-fourth. Across the first column a bracket is labeled one-fourth. Along the left side of the square, the rows are labeled one-fifth. Across the first row a bracket is labeled one-fifth.

hints.content: What is $\blueE{\dfrac15}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac14}$?   We can see that $1$ of the $20$ equal parts from the whole unit has stripes.    $\blueE{\dfrac15}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac14}=\dfrac1{20}$

We can also solve with multiplication.  $\blueE{\dfrac15}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac14}$ is another way of saying $\blueE{\dfrac15} \times \purpleE{\dfrac14}$.  So we can calculate the area of the striped rectangle by multiplying its $\blueE{\text{height}} \times \purpleE{\text{width}}$.

$\begin{align} \text{Area of striped rectangle} &= \blueE{\text{height}} \times \purpleE{\text{width}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac15} \times \purpleE{\dfrac14}\\\\ & = \dfrac{\blueE{1} \times \purpleE{1}}{\blueE{5} \times \purpleE{4}}\\\\ & = \dfrac{1}{20} \end{align}$
The area of the striped rectangle is $\dfrac{1}{20}$ of a square unit.

question.content: The area of the entire figure below is $1$ square unit.     Use the striped area to help solve the multiplication problem.      **What is $\dfrac{3}{4}$ of $\dfrac{2}{5}$?**     of a square unit

images.alt: A square that has been split into 20 parts, set in 5 rows of 4 parts each. The first three parts in the top 2 rows are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple. The fourth parts in the top 2 rows have been shaded blue. The first three parts in the bottom 3 rows have been shaded purple. The fourth  parts in the bottom 3 rows are unshaded. Along the top of the square, the columns are labeled one-fourth. Along the left side of the square, the rows are labeled one-fifth.

hints.content: The area of the entire figure is $1$ square unit.  [[☃ image 1]]  The striped rectangle is $\purpleE{\dfrac34}$ of a unit wide.  Only $\blueE{\dfrac25}$ of the $\purpleE{\dfrac34}$ of the unit is striped.

images.alt: A square that has been split into 20 parts, set in 5 rows of 4 parts each. The first three parts in the top 2 rows are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple. The fourth parts in the top 2 rows have been shaded blue. The first three parts in the bottom 3 rows have been shaded purple. The fourth  parts in the bottom 3 rows are unshaded. Along the top of the square, the columns are labeled one-fourth. Across the first 3 columns a bracket is labeled three-fourths. Along the left side of the square, the rows are labeled one-fifth. Across the first 2 rows a bracket is labeled two-fifths.

hints.content: What is $\blueE{\dfrac25}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac34}$?   We can see that $6$ of the $20$ equal parts from the whole unit has stripes.    $\blueE{\dfrac25}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac34}=\dfrac6{20}$

We can also solve with multiplication.  $\blueE{\dfrac25}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac34}$ is another way of saying $\blueE{\dfrac25} \times \purpleE{\dfrac34}$.  So we can calculate the area of the striped rectangle by multiplying its $\blueE{\text{height}} \times \purpleE{\text{width}}$.

$\begin{align} \text{Area of striped rectangle} &= \blueE{\text{height}} \times \purpleE{\text{width}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac25} \times \purpleE{\dfrac34}\\\\ & = \dfrac{\blueE{2} \times \purpleE{3}}{\blueE{5} \times \purpleE{4}}\\\\ & = \dfrac{6}{20} \end{align}$

We can rewrite $\dfrac{6}{20}$ as an equivalent fraction.  $\begin{align} \dfrac{6}{20}&=\dfrac{3 \times 2}{10 \times 2}\\\\ &=\dfrac{3}{10}\times\dfrac{2}{2}\\\\ &=\dfrac{3}{10}\times1\\\\ &=\dfrac{3}{10} \end{align}$
The area of the striped rectangle is $\dfrac{3}{10}$ of a square unit.

question.content: The area of the entire figure below is $1$ square unit.    Use the striped area to help solve the multiplication problem.    **What is $\dfrac{5}{6}$ of $\dfrac{3}{4}$?**     of a square unit

images.alt: A rectangle that has been split into 24 parts, set in 4 rows of 6 parts each. The parts in the top 3 rows have been shaded blue. The parts in the left 5 columns have been shaded purple. The first 5 parts in the top 3 rows are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple. Along the top of the rectangle, the columns are labeled one-sixth.  Along the left side of the rectangle, the rows are labeled one-fourth.

hints.content: The area of the entire figure is $1$ square unit.   [[☃ image 1]]  The striped rectangle is $\purpleE{\dfrac56}$ of a unit wide.  Only $\blueE{\dfrac34}$ of the $\purpleE{\dfrac56}$ of the unit is striped.

images.alt: A rectangle that has been split into 24 parts, set in 4 rows of 6 parts each. The parts in the top 3 rows have been shaded blue. The parts in the left 5 columns have been shaded purple. The first 5 parts in the top 3 rows are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple. Along the top of the rectangle, the columns are labeled one-sixth. Across the first 5 columns a bracket is labeled five-sixths. Along the left side of the rectangle, the rows are labeled one-fourth. Across the first 3 rows a bracket is labeled three-fourths.

hints.content: What is $\blueE{\dfrac34}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac56}$?   We can see that $15$ of the $24$ equal parts from the whole unit has stripes.    $\blueE{\dfrac34}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac56}=\dfrac{15}{24}$

We can also solve with multiplication.  $\blueE{\dfrac34}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac56}$ is another way of saying $\blueE{\dfrac34} \times \purpleE{\dfrac56}$.  So we can calculate the area of the striped rectangle by multiplying its $\blueE{\text{height}} \times \purpleE{\text{width}}$.

$\begin{align} \text{Area of striped rectangle} &= \blueE{\text{height}} \times \purpleE{\text{width}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac34} \times \purpleE{\dfrac56}\\\\ & = \dfrac{\blueE{3} \times \purpleE{5}}{\blueE{4} \times \purpleE{6}}\\\\ & = \dfrac{15}{24} \end{align}$

We can rewrite $\dfrac{15}{24}$ as an equivalent fraction.  $\begin{align} \dfrac{15}{24}&=\dfrac{5 \times 3}{8 \times 3}\\\\ &=\dfrac{5}{8}\times\dfrac{3}{3}\\\\ &=\dfrac{5}{8}\times1\\\\ &=\dfrac{5}{8} \end{align}$
The area of the striped rectangle is $\dfrac{5}{8}$ of a square unit.

question.content: The area of the entire figure below is $1$ square unit.       Use the striped area to help solve the multiplication problem.      **What is $\dfrac{4}{7}$ of $\dfrac{2}{3}$?**     of a square unit

images.alt: A square that has been split into 21 parts, set in 3 rows of 7 parts each. The first four parts in the top 2 rows are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple. The rest of the parts in the top 2 rows have been shaded blue. The first four parts in the bottom row have been shaded purple. The rest of the parts in the bottom row are unshaded. Along the top of the square, the columns are labeled one-seventh. Along the left side of the square, the rows are labeled one-third.

hints.content: The area of the entire figure is $1$ square unit.  [[☃ image 1]]  The striped rectangle is $\purpleE{\dfrac47}$ of a unit wide.  Only $\blueE{\dfrac23}$ of the $\purpleE{\dfrac47}$ of the unit is striped.

images.alt: A square that has been split into 21 parts set in 3 rows of 7 parts each. The first four parts in the top 2 rows are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple. The rest of the parts in the top 2 rows have been shaded blue. The first four parts in the bottom row have been shaded purple. The rest of the parts in the bottom row are unshaded. Along the top of the square, the columns are labeled one-seventh. Across the first 4 columns a bracket is labeled four-sevenths. Along the left side of the square, the rows are labeled one-third. Across the first 2 rows a bracket is labeled two-thirds.

hints.content: What is $\blueE{\dfrac23}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac47}$?   We can see that $8$ of the $21$ equal parts from the whole unit has stripes.    $\blueE{\dfrac23}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac47}=\dfrac{8}{21}$

We can also solve with multiplication.  $\blueE{\dfrac23}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac47}$ is another way of saying $\blueE{\dfrac23} \times \purpleE{\dfrac47}$.  So we can calculate the area of the striped rectangle by multiplying its $\blueE{\text{height}} \times \purpleE{\text{width}}$.

$\begin{align} \text{Area of striped rectangle} &= \blueE{\text{height}} \times \purpleE{\text{width}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac23} \times \purpleE{\dfrac47}\\\\ & = \dfrac{\blueE{2} \times \purpleE{4}}{\blueE{3} \times \purpleE{7}}\\\\ & = \dfrac{8}{21} \end{align}$
The area of the striped rectangle is $\dfrac{8}{21}$ of a square unit.

question.content: The area of each square below is $1$ square unit.      Use the striped area to help solve the multiplication problem.      **What is $\dfrac{4}{3}$ of $\dfrac{2}{5}$?**   of a square unit

images.alt: Two equal-sized squares side by side. Each square  has been split into 15 parts, set in 5 rows of 3 parts each. In the first square, the parts in the bottom 3 rows have been shaded purple and the parts in the top 2 rows are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple. In the second square, the first parts in the top 2 rows are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple and the last three parts in the top 2 rows have been shaded blue. The first parts in the bottom 3 rows have been shaded purple and the last two parts in the bottom 3 rows are unshaded. Along the top of both squares, the columns are labeled one-third. Along the left side of the squares the rows are labeled one-fifth.

hints.content: The area of the each square below is $1$ square unit.  [[☃ image 1]]  The striped rectangle is $\purpleE{\dfrac43}$ of a unit wide.  Only $\blueE{\dfrac25}$ of the $\purpleE{\dfrac43}$ of the unit is striped.

images.alt: Two equal-sized squares side by side. Each square  has been split into 15 parts, set in 5 rows of 3 parts each. In the first square, the parts in the bottom 3 rows have been shaded purple and the parts in the top 2 rows are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple. In the second square, the first parts in the top 2 rows are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple and the last three parts in the top 2 rows have been shaded blue. The first parts in the bottom 3 rows have been shaded purple and the last two parts in the bottom 3 rows are unshaded. Along the top of both squares, the columns are labeled one-third. Across the first 4 columns a bracket is labeled fourth-thirds. Along the left side of the squares the rows are labeled one-fifth. Across the first 2 rows a bracket is labeled two-fifths.

hints.content: What is $\blueE{\dfrac25}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac43}$?   We can see that $8$ equal parts are striped. There are $15$ equal parts in one whole unit.  $\blueE{\dfrac25}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac43}=\dfrac{8}{15}$

We can also solve with multiplication.  $\blueE{\dfrac25}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac43}$ is another way of saying $\blueE{\dfrac25} \times \purpleE{\dfrac43}$.  So we can calculate the area of the striped rectangle by multiplying its $\blueE{\text{height}} \times \purpleE{\text{width}}$.

$\begin{align} \text{Area of striped rectangle} &= \blueE{\text{height}} \times \purpleE{\text{width}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac25} \times \purpleE{\dfrac43}\\\\ & = \dfrac{\blueE{2} \times \purpleE{4}}{\blueE{5} \times \purpleE{3}}\\\\ & = \dfrac{8}{15} \end{align}$
The area of the striped region is $\dfrac{8}{15}$ of a square unit.

question.content: The area of each square below is $1$ square unit.      Use the striped area to help solve the multiplication problem.      **What is $\dfrac{3}{2}$ of $\dfrac{3}{6}$?**      of a square unit

images.alt: Two equal-sized squares side by side. Each square  has been split into 12 parts, set in 6 rows of 2 parts each. In the first square, the parts in the bottom 3 rows have been shaded purple and the parts in the top 3 rows are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple. In the second square, the first parts in the top 3 rows are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple and the last parts in the top 3 rows have been shaded blue. The first parts in the bottom 3 rows have been shaded purple and the last  parts in the bottom 3 rows are unshaded. Along the top of both squares, the columns are labeled one-half. Along the left side of the squares the rows are labeled one-sixth.

hints.content: The area of the each square below is $1$ square unit.   [[☃ image 1]]  The striped rectangle is $\purpleE{\dfrac32}$ of a unit wide.  Only $\blueE{\dfrac36}$ of the $\purpleE{\dfrac32}$ of the unit is striped.

images.alt: Two equal-sized squares side by side. Each square  has been split into 12 parts, set in 6 rows of 2 parts each. In the first square, the parts in the bottom 3 rows have been shaded purple and the parts in the top 3 rows are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple. In the second square, the first parts in the top 3 rows are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple and the last parts in the top 3 rows have been shaded blue. The first parts in the bottom 3 rows have been shaded purple and the last  parts in the bottom 3 rows are unshaded. Along the top of both squares, the columns are labeled one-half.  Across the first 3 columns a bracket is labeled three-halves. Along the left side of the squares the rows are labeled one-sixth. Across the first 3 rows a bracket is labeled three-sixths.

hints.content: What is $\blueE{\dfrac36}$ of $\purpleD{\dfrac32}$?  We can see that $9$ equal parts are striped. There are $12$ equal parts in one whole unit.  $\blueE{\dfrac36}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac32}=\dfrac{9}{12}$

We can also solve with multiplication.  $\blueE{\dfrac36}$ of $\purpleE{\dfrac32}$ is another way of saying $\blueE{\dfrac36} \times \purpleE{\dfrac32}$.  So we can calculate the area of the striped rectangle by multiplying its $\blueE{\text{height}} \times \purpleE{\text{width}}$.

$\begin{align} \text{Area of striped rectangle} &= \blueE{\text{height}} \times \purpleE{\text{width}}\\\\ &= \blueE{\dfrac36} \times \purpleE{\dfrac32}\\\\ & = \dfrac{\blueE{3} \times \purpleE{3}}{\blueE{6} \times \purpleE{2}}\\\\ & = \dfrac{9}{12} \end{align}$

We can rewrite $\dfrac{9}{12}$ as an equivalent fraction.  $\begin{align} \dfrac{9}{12}&=\dfrac{3 \times 3}{4 \times 3}\\\\ &=\dfrac{3}{4}\times\dfrac{3}{3}\\\\ &=\dfrac{3}{4}\times1\\\\ &=\dfrac{3}{4} \end{align}$
The area of the striped region is $\dfrac{3}{4}$ of a square unit.

question.content: Use the tape diagram below to help solve the multiplication problem.       **What is $\dfrac12$ of $\dfrac67?$**

images.alt: A tape diagram has been divided into seven equal parts. 3 parts are darkly shaded, 3 parts are lightly shaded, and 1 part is not shaded. Across the bar, a curved bracket is labeled 1. Below the 3 darkly shaded parts, a curved bracket is labeled with a question mark.

hints.content: The *whole* has $7$ equal pieces, with $6$ pieces shaded.  [[☃ image 1]]  The shaded parts represent $\dfrac{6}{7}$ of $1$ whole.

images.alt: A tape diagram has been divided into seven equal parts. 6 parts are lightly shaded and 1 part is not shaded. Across the bar, a curved bracket is labeled 1. Below the 6 lightly shaded parts, a curved bracket is labeled sixth-sevenths.

hints.content: The *shaded parts* have $6$ equal pieces, with $3$ pieces marked.   [[☃ image 1]]  The selected parts represent $\dfrac{3}{6}$ of $\dfrac{6}{7}$.

images.alt: A tape diagram has been divided into seven equal parts. 3 parts are darkly shaded, 3 parts are lightly shaded, and 1 part is not shaded. Below the 3 darkly shaded parts, a curved bracket is labeled three-sixths of six-sevenths.

hints.content: $\dfrac{3}{6}$ is equivalent to $\dfrac{1}{2}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  So the selected parts represent $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of $\dfrac{6}{7}$.

images.alt: A tape diagram has been divided into seven equal parts. 3 parts are darkly shaded, 3 parts are lightly shaded, and 1 part is not shaded. A blue line is between the third darkly shaded part and the fourth lightly shaded part. Below the 3 darkly shaded parts, a curved bracket is labeled one-half of six-sevenths.

hints.content: What is $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of $\dfrac{6}{7}$?  The whole is divided into $7$ equal parts and $3$ are shaded.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of $\dfrac{6}{7}=\dfrac37$

images.alt: A tape diagram has been divided into seven equal parts. 3 parts are darkly shaded, 3 parts are lightly shaded, and 1 part is not shaded. Across the bar, a curved bracket is labeled 1. Below the 3 darkly shaded parts, a curved bracket is labeled three-sevenths.

hints.content: We can also solve using multiplication.    $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of $\dfrac{6}{7}$ is another way of saying $\dfrac{1}{2} \times \dfrac{6}{7}$.
$\begin{align} \dfrac12\text{ of }\dfrac67& = \dfrac12 \times \dfrac67\\\\ &=\dfrac{1 \times 6}{2 \times 7}\\\\ &= \dfrac{6}{14} \end{align}$

We can rewrite $\dfrac{6}{14}$ as an equivalent fraction.  $\begin{align} \dfrac{6}{14}&=\dfrac{3 \times 2}{7 \times 2}\\\\ &=\dfrac{3}{7}\times\dfrac{2}{2}\\\\ &=\dfrac{3}{7}\times1\\\\ &=\dfrac{3}{7} \end{align}$
$\dfrac12$ of $\dfrac67$ is $\dfrac37$ .

question.content: Use the tape diagram below to help solve the multiplication problem.      **What is $\dfrac12$ of $\dfrac89?$**

images.alt: A tape diagram has been divided into nine equal parts. 4 parts are darkly shaded, 4 parts are lightly shaded, and 1 part is not shaded. Across the bar, a curved bracket is labeled 1. Below the 4 darkly shaded parts, a curved bracket is labeled with a question mark.

hints.content: The *whole* has $9$ equal pieces, with $8$ pieces shaded.  [[☃ image 1]]  The shaded parts represent $\dfrac89$ of $1$ whole.

images.alt: A tape diagram has been divided into nine equal parts. 8 parts are lightly shaded and 1 part is not shaded. Across the bar, a curved bracket is labeled 1. Below the 8 lightly shaded parts, a curved bracket is labeled eight-ninths.

hints.content: The *shaded parts* have $8$ equal pieces, with $4$ pieces marked.  [[☃ image 1]]  The selected parts represent $\dfrac48$ of $\dfrac89$.

images.alt: A tape diagram has been divided into nine equal parts. 4 parts are darkly shaded, 4 parts are lightly shaded, and 1 part is not shaded. Below the 4 darkly shaded parts, a curved bracket is labeled four-eighths of eight-ninths.

hints.content: $\dfrac48$ is equivalent to $\dfrac{1}{2}$.  [[☃ image 1]]  So the selected parts represent $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of $\dfrac89$.

images.alt: A tape diagram has been divided into nine equal parts. 4 parts are darkly shaded, 4 parts are lightly shaded, and 1 part is not shaded. An orange line is between the fourth darkly shaded part and the fifth lightly shaded part. Below the 4 darkly shaded parts, a curved bracket is labeled one-half of eight-ninths.

hints.content: What is $\dfrac12$ of $\dfrac89$?  The whole is divided into $9$ equal parts and $4$ are shaded.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\dfrac12$ of $\dfrac89=\dfrac49$

images.alt: A tape diagram has been divided into nine equal parts. 4 parts are darkly shaded, 4 parts are lightly shaded, and 1 part is not shaded. Below the 4 darkly shaded parts, a curved bracket is labeled four-ninths.

hints.content: We can also solve using multiplication.    $\dfrac12$ of $\dfrac89$ is another way of saying $\dfrac1 2\times \dfrac89$.
$\begin{align} \dfrac12\text{ of }\dfrac89& = \dfrac12 \times \dfrac89\\\\ &=\dfrac{1 \times 8}{2 \times 9}\\\\ &= \dfrac{8}{18} \end{align}$
We can rewrite $\dfrac{8}{18}$ as an equivalent fraction.  $\begin{align} \dfrac{8}{18}&=\dfrac{4 \times 2}{9 \times 2}\\\\ &=\dfrac49\times\dfrac22\\\\ &=\dfrac49\times1\\\\ &=\dfrac49 \end{align}$
$\dfrac12$ of $\dfrac89$ is $\dfrac49$ .

question.content: Use the tape diagram below to help solve the multiplication problem.       **What is $\dfrac23$ of $\dfrac38?$**

images.alt: A tape diagram has been divided into eight equal parts. 2 parts are darkly shaded, 1 part is lightly shaded, and 5 parts are not shaded. Across the bar, a curved bracket is labeled 1. Below the 2 darkly shaded parts, a curved bracket is labeled with a question mark.

hints.content: The *whole* has $8$ equal pieces, with $3$ pieces shaded.  [[☃ image 1]]  The shaded parts represent $\dfrac38$ of $1$ whole.

images.alt: A tape diagram has been divided into eight equal parts. 3 parts are lightly shaded and 5 parts are not shaded. Across the bar, a curved bracket is labeled 1. Below the 3 lightly shaded parts, a curved bracket is labeled three-eighths.

hints.content: The *shaded parts* have $3$ equal pieces, with $2$ pieces marked.   [[☃ image 1]]  The selected parts represent $\dfrac23$ of $\dfrac38$.

images.alt: A tape diagram has been divided into eight equal parts.  2 parts are darkly shaded, 1 part is lightly shaded, and 5 parts are not shaded. Below the 2 darkly shaded parts, a curved bracket is labeled with two-thirds of three-eighths.

hints.content: What is $\dfrac23$ of $\dfrac38$?  The whole is divided into $8$ equal parts and $2$ are shaded.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\dfrac23$ of $\dfrac38=\dfrac28$

images.alt: A tape diagram has been divided into eight equal parts. 2 parts are darkly shaded, 1 part is lightly shaded, and 5 parts are not shaded. Below the 2 darkly shaded parts, a curved bracket is labeled with two-eighths equals one-fourth.

hints.content: We can also solve using multiplication.    $\dfrac23$ of $\dfrac38$ is another way of saying $\dfrac23 \times \dfrac38$.
$\begin{align} \dfrac23\text{ of }\dfrac38& = \dfrac23 \times \dfrac38\\\\ &=\dfrac{2 \times 3}{3 \times 8}\\\\ &= \dfrac{6}{24} \end{align}$
We can rewrite $\dfrac{6}{24}$ as an equivalent fraction.  $\begin{align} \dfrac{6}{24}&=\dfrac{1 \times 6}{4 \times 6}\\\\ &=\dfrac14\times\dfrac66\\\\ &=\dfrac14\times1\\\\ &=\dfrac14 \end{align}$
$\dfrac23$ of $\dfrac38$ is $\dfrac14$ .

question.content: Use the tape diagram below to help solve the multiplication problem.      **What is $\dfrac58$ of $\dfrac45?$**

images.alt: A fraction bar has been divided into five equal parts. Each part has been further divided into two smaller parts, for a total of 10 smaller parts.  5 parts are darkly shaded, 3 parts are lightly shaded light, and 2 parts are not shaded.  Across the bar, a curved bracket is labeled 1.  Below the 5 darkly shaded parts, a curved bracket is labeled question mark.

hints.content: The *whole* has $5$ equal pieces, with $4$ pieces shaded.    [[☃ image 1]]  The shaded parts represent $\dfrac45$ of $1$ whole.

images.alt: A fraction bar divided into 5 equal parts. Above the entire bar, a curved bracket is labeled 1. The first four parts are shaded. Below the four shaded parts, a curved bracket is labeled four-fifths.

hints.content: The *shaded parts* have $8$ equal pieces, with $5$ pieces marked.   [[☃ image 1]]  The selected parts represent $\dfrac58$ of $\dfrac45$.

images.alt: A fraction bar has been divided into five equal parts. Each part has been further divided into two smaller parts, for a total of 10 smaller parts.  5 parts are darkly shaded, 3 parts are lightly shaded light, and 2 parts are not shaded.   Below the 5 darkly shaded parts, a curved bracket is labeled five-eighths of four-fifths.

hints.content: What is $\dfrac58$ of $\dfrac45$?  The whole is divided into $10$ equal parts and $5$ are shaded.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\dfrac58$ of $\dfrac45=\dfrac5{10}$

images.alt: A fraction bar has been divided into five equal parts. Each part has been further divided into two smaller parts, for a total of 10 smaller parts.  5 parts are darkly shaded, 3 parts are lightly shaded light, and 2 parts are not shaded.   Below the 5 darkly shaded parts, a curved bracket is labeled five-tenths equals one-half.

hints.content: We can also solve using multiplication.    $\dfrac58$ of $\dfrac45$ is another way of saying $\dfrac58\times \dfrac45$.
$\begin{align} \dfrac58\text{ of }\dfrac45& = \dfrac58 \times \dfrac45\\\\ &=\dfrac{5 \times 4}{8 \times 5}\\\\ &= \dfrac{20}{40} \end{align}$

We can rewrite $\dfrac{20}{40}$ as an equivalent fraction.  $\begin{align} \dfrac{20}{40}&=\dfrac{1 \times 20}{2 \times 20}\\\\ &=\dfrac12\times\dfrac{20}{20}\\\\ &=\dfrac12\times1\\\\ &=\dfrac12 \end{align}$
$\dfrac58$ of $\dfrac45$ is $\dfrac12$ .

question.content: Use the tape diagram below to help solve the multiplication problem.      **What is $\dfrac12$ of $\dfrac23?$**

images.alt: A tape diagram has been divided into three equal parts. 1 part is darkly shaded, 1 part is lightly shaded, and 1 part is not shaded. Across the bar, a curved bracket is labeled 1. Below the darkly shaded part, a curved bracket is labeled with a question mark.

hints.content: The *whole* has $3$ equal pieces, with $2$ pieces shaded.  [[☃ image 1]]  The shaded parts represent $\dfrac23$ of $1$ whole.

images.alt: A tape diagram has been divided into three equal parts. 2 parts are lightly shaded and 1 part is not shaded. Across the bar, a curved bracket is labeled 1. Below the 2 lightly shaded parts, a curved bracket is labeled two-thirds.

hints.content: The *shaded parts* have $2$ equal pieces, with $1$ piece marked.  [[☃ image 1]]  The selected parts represent $\dfrac12$ of $\dfrac{2}{3}$.

images.alt: A tape diagram has been divided into three equal parts. 1 part is darkly shaded, 1 part is lightly shaded, and 1 part is not shaded.  Below the darkly shaded part, a curved bracket is labeled one-half of two-thirds.

hints.content: What is $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of $\dfrac23$?  The whole is divided into $3$ equal parts and $1$ is shaded.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of $\dfrac23=\dfrac13$

images.alt: A tape diagram has been divided into three equal parts. 1 part is darkly shaded, 1 part is lightly shaded, and 1 part is not shaded.  Below the darkly shaded part, a curved bracket is labeled one-third.

hints.content: We can also solve using multiplication.    $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of $\dfrac23$ is another way of saying $\dfrac{1}{2} \times \dfrac23$.
$\begin{align} \dfrac12\text{ of }\dfrac23& = \dfrac12 \times \dfrac23\\\\ &=\dfrac{1 \times 2}{2 \times 3}\\\\ &= \dfrac{2}{6} \end{align}$

We can rewrite $\dfrac{2}{6}$ as an equivalent fraction.  $\begin{align} \dfrac{2}{6}&=\dfrac{1 \times 2}{3 \times 2}\\\\ &=\dfrac13\times\dfrac{2}{2}\\\\ &=\dfrac13\times1\\\\ &=\dfrac13 \end{align}$
$\dfrac12$ of $\dfrac23$ is $\dfrac13$ .

question.content: Use the tape diagram below to help solve the multiplication problem.       **What is $\dfrac13$ of $\dfrac95?$**

images.alt: Two fraction bars. Each is divided into five equal parts. A curved bracket above each fraction bar is labeled 1. In the first fraction bar, 3 parts are darkly shaded and the other two sections are lightly shaded.  In the second fraction bar, four sections are lightly shaded. A curved bracket under the three darkly shaded sections is labeled question mark.

hints.content: Each *whole* has $5$ equal pieces, with $9$ pieces shaded.   [[☃ image 1]]  The shaded parts represent $\dfrac95$.

images.alt: Two fraction bars. Each is divided into five equal parts. A curved bracket above each fraction bar is labeled 1. In the first fraction bar, all five parts are shaded. In the second fraction bar, four parts are shaded. A curved bracket under the 9 shaded parts is labeled nine-fifths.

hints.content: The *shaded parts* have $9$ equal pieces, with $3$ pieces marked.   [[☃ image 1]]  The selected parts represent $\dfrac39$ of $\dfrac95$.

images.alt: Two fraction bars. Each is divided into five equal parts. In the first fraction bar, 3 parts are darkly shaded and the other 2 parts are lightly shaded. In the second fraction bar, four parts are lightly shaded. A curved bracket under the 3 darkly shaded parts is labeled three-ninths of nine-fifths.

hints.content: $\dfrac{3}{9}$ is equivalent to $\dfrac{1}{3}$.    [[☃ image 1]]  So the selected parts represent $\dfrac{1}{3}$ of $\dfrac{9}{5}$.

images.alt: Two fraction bars. Each is divided into five equal parts. In the first fraction bar, 3 parts are darkly shaded and the other 2 parts are lightly shaded. In the second fraction bar, 4 parts are lightly shaded. A line has been drawn after the 3 darkly shaded parts in the first fraction bar. In the second fraction bar, a line has been drawn after the first part. Together, these two lines show three groups: a group of three darkly shaded bars, a group of three lightly shaded bars, and a final group of three lightly shaded bars. A curved bracket under the group of three darkly shaded parts is labeled one-third of nine-fifths.

hints.content: What is $\dfrac13$ of $\dfrac95$?  Each whole is divided into $5$ equal parts and $3$ are shaded.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\dfrac13$ of $\dfrac95=\dfrac3{5}$

images.alt: Two fraction bars. Each is divided into five equal parts. In the first fraction bar, three parts are darkly shaded and the other two part are lightly shaded. In the second fraction bar, four parts are lightly shaded. A curved bracket under the three darkly shaded parts is labeled three-fifths.

hints.content: We can also solve using multiplication.    $\dfrac13$ of $\dfrac95$ is another way of saying $\dfrac13\times \dfrac95$.
$\begin{align} \dfrac13\text{ of }\dfrac95& = \dfrac13 \times \dfrac95\\\\ &=\dfrac{1 \times 9}{3 \times 5}\\\\ &= \dfrac{9}{15} \end{align}$
We can rewrite $\dfrac{9}{15}$ as an equivalent fraction.  $\begin{align} \dfrac{9}{15}&=\dfrac{3 \times 3}{5 \times 3}\\\\ &=\dfrac35\times\dfrac33\\\\ &=\dfrac35\times1\\\\ &=\dfrac35 \end{align}$
$\dfrac13$ of $\dfrac95$ is $\dfrac35$ .
